This is a great rpg and great series, if you enjoy turn based RPG give this a try its alot of fun

My reviews are always based on the following

reviewText: Eschalon: Book 2 is a sequel to Book 1 and therefore similar in everything it does. There are minor improvements, like faster walking, higher resolution, more skills... but nothing of great importance. Eschalon is a turn-based role-playing game series with astounding graphics and sound. Unfortunately gameplay is a bit slow, even for an ultima-like game. Doing almost anything in this game is fun but one thing: Walking. And there's a lot of walking. Walking through forests, walking through beaches, walking through deserts... and even more walking. The game has interesting dungeons and towns, filled with many secrets and details, unfortunately other locations are there just to be walked through. That is why I would rate this game as decent: It's a very enjoyable RPG, except for tedious walking through wilderness.

reviewText: I got this on sale for $5, and after playing it for over a dozen hours, I'm already thinking it's one of the best indie" computer RPG's. It's like the older Elder Scrolls games
date: but with Ultima-style graphics and interface. It has a freely explorable world that is viewed in a 3rd person
recommended: top-down perspective. Resolution is limited to 1024x768. But I actually dig the graphics and interface. What I dig even more is how *challenging* this RPG is
hoursPlayed: and how you can build and play your character in very different ways to deal with those challenges. It's not an action RPG
voteText: like Diablo; it's more of a thinking man's RPG
helpfulPercent: like Elder Scrolls. (Eventhough a big part of that challenge can be a pain
votesHelpful: dealing with darkness and thirst/hunger and equipment wear/breakage.) Combat is a tactical blend of turn-based and real-time. Keeping your character alive can be hard
votesTotal: especially if you're not paying attention and if you're not putting enough thought into how you build and play your character."

reviewText: If you like good old Ultima-style (or a bit more advanced Diablo-looking) RPG's, with a darn good setting, Eschalon Book's your call. It's got a sensible story, loads to explore, blockades to explode and traps to exploit against your many newfound enemies.

reviewText: Book 2 чувствуется уже не столько данью почтения канувшим в лету CRPG, сколько самостоятельная игра, вполне способная жить и существовать отдельно от воспоминаний породивших ее. Как и первая часть, игра определенно не для всех, но это умное, гармонично сложенное приключение, которое с удовольствием выведет вас за рамки комфорта, тем самым подарив уникальный игровой опыт.

column19: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I've tried to enjoy Eschalon: Book II, and it really is a game fully inside my usual wheelhouse.  RPG... check.  Mouse-driven combat... check.  Unforgiving difficulty... check.  Sidequests... check.  Lots of interesting text to read... CHECK!

So why can't I recommend this?  It's the controls.  There is a simple flaw in this game's design that makes for a really poor experience when I play:

You have to hold down the mouse button to walk.

This might not seem like a big deal, but when I'm going to be playing a game for hours, this becomes painful quite quickly.  It isn't a click-fest like Diablo; it's both lots of clicking and LOTS of holding down the mouse button for long periods of time.

Otherwise, Eschalon: Book II is a quite excellently made game.  If I were to recommend an alternative, I would point to the recent Spiderweb Software games, which are probably superior to the Eschalon series anyway.

reviewText: If you are a old school rpg fan that like turned based combat with survival aspects and many gameplay mechanics I recommend this. Its a fun game,lots of ways to personally build your characters and different ways to play.Think  you can just run around looting chests and such? Not in this game if a npc sees you rob them they will come after you to attack you. You can even kill the npcs if you want to.\n\nEschalon Book 3 is coming out Summer 2013 so if you do not want this one,I would say wait for that one.It is going to have many improvements from the 2nd and I imagine lots more content.

reviewText: Eschalon: Book II is a game you have to have  history to appreciate. If you grew up on classic crpgs, then you may know the score. You just have to find that perfect afternoon to play it. Preferably one where you are thinking back to the first computer rpg games you fell in love with. It is a tough game, but it is rewarding and fun. You can watch a few Let's Plays" and get an idea
date: but until you pick it up you will not understand what makes it great. My simple yes or no scale: Yes
recommended: buy it. Many of us pine for those halcyon days of PCRPGS. This is your time machine back."

reviewText: Much like the game that came before it, the only thing that has improved is the graphical quality.  Trudge slowly through open fields to use the same two skills against the same enemies through similar locations for dozens of hours you will never get to live again!  It tries to slam Diablo in its description, but it's essentially the same as a dumbed-down version of Diablo that's turn-based in spite of not having the depth to justify such a choice.  I bought this on sale for about a dollar, and still regretted it.

Here is the dictionary topic you requested. The following information is member-contributed. Have a better explanation for this topic? Append your information!

Banmaster B

Posted by netwerk23 on February 12, 2004

Hilarious admin pseudo-gimmick who, for a brief time, would ban people with a rap extolling the banned poster's moronity. Vanished as quickly as he arrived.

Posted by You Am I on February 12, 2004

Banmaster B and his close friend, Captain Yams! were shell accounts used by administrators to ban people back in the early days of the forums to ban people so that administrator would not be dragged into drama for banning a possible favourite goon.

After a while the admins didn't care what other goons had to say about the goon they banned, and those shell accounts were abandoned.

reviewText: If you've played Eshcalon Book I, then book II should be pretty easy to predict in terms of gameplay\nBook II does the same things book I does, only it adds a combat stance mechanic (Which may look all cool and fancy, but it's not for option" You actually need this) it also introduces Hunger & Thirst. Personally I think this is just a hold back because all it does is force you to backtrack. However
recommended: it handles these mechanics the same way: The game is against you. You need to be smart about how you play the game
hoursPlayed: and it actually adds challenge to the game. IF you liked the first book
voteText: you will like this one too!"

reviewText:
I really love this game. You get to play just one character (making it personal), instead of having to manage an entire party (making it just about stats).

Cons: Although they upgraded the size of the graphics on screen (from book1), book2 still is not capable of displaying 1080p. If I remember right, there ends up being a significant portion of unused realestate on your monitor, unless you lower your desktop screen size.
Cons: Enemies do not respawn ever. (No xp harvesting.)

Pros: This game is awesome.
Pros: Single character with level based progression.
Pros: Enemies do not respawn ever. (No worrying about running through an area due to low health or not wanting to be bothered with fights.)
Pros: Magic system is fun!

Pros: Can edit the save file very easily, combining items to save space or make artifacts so you can finish the game and get to the next game cause there is not enough time to play all your games even once, without cheating.
Cons: Save file takes time to understand.
